message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations
Paper Abstract: Social conventions are the backbone of social coordination, shaping how individuals form a group. As growing populations of artificial intelligence (AI) agents communicate through natural language, a fundamental question is whether they can bootstrap the foundations of a society. Here, we present experimental results that demonstrate the spontaneous emergence of universally adopted social conventions in decentralized populations of large language model (LLM) agents. We then show how strong collective biases can emerge during this process, even when agents exhibit no bias individually. Last, we examine how committed minority groups of adversarial LLM agents can drive social change by imposing alternative social conventions on the larger population. Our results show that AI systems can autonomously develop social conventions without explicit programming and have implications for designing AI systems that align, and remain aligned, with human values and societal goals.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Composition and Characteristics

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and typically refer to software agents, though agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Key characteristics include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications

Web search results for query: "Collective bias"

Links: [{"title":"Shared information bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_information_bias"},{"title":"Pluralistic ignorance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pluralistic_ignorance"},{"title":"List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases"},{"title":"Michael Muthukrishna - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Muthukrishna"},{"title":"Group decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_decision-making"},{"title":"Gérald Bronner - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%A9rald_Bronner"},{"title":"Metadynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metadynamics"}]

Based on the search results, "collective bias" can refer to several related concepts in social psychology and cognitive science:

## Shared Information Bias

One form of collective bias is the shared information bias (also known as the collective information sampling bias, or common-information bias), which is the tendency for group members to spend more time and energy discussing information that all members are already familiar with (i.e., shared information), and less time and energy discussing information that only some members are aware of (i.e., unshared information).(no content)Harmful consequences related to poor decision-making can arise when the group does not have access to unshared information (hidden profiles) in order to make a well-informed decision.

## Pluralistic Ignorance (Collective Illusion)

Another related phenomenon is pluralistic ignorance (also known as a collective illusion), a phenomenon in which people mistakenly believe that others predominantly hold an opinion different from their own.(no content)In such cases, many people in a group may go along with a view they do not hold because they think, incorrectly, that most other people in the group hold it.

## Availability Cascade

Additionally, an availability cascade is a self-reinforcing process in which a collective belief gains more and more plausibility through its increasing repetition in public discourse.

These biases collectively affect how groups make decisions and form beliefs, often leading to suboptimal outcomes due to systematic patterns in how information is processed and shared among group members.

Web search results for query: "Artificial intelligence agent"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Percept (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percept_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about artificial intelligence agents:

## Definition

An intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Types of AI Agents

There are several categories of AI agents:

- **Autonomous Agents**: An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

- **Agentic AI**: In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.

- **Embodied Agents**: An embodied agent is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment.

## How Agents Work

Agents perceive their environment using sensors and act upon it using actuators—for example, a robot with cameras and wheels, or a software program that reads data and makes recommendations.(no content)A rational agent strives to achieve the best possible outcome based on its knowledge and past experiences, with "best" being defined by a performance measure.

## Modern Applications

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.(no content)By December 2025, the Department of Neighborhoods in Detroit, Michigan deployed a pilot project for an AI agent to be used for customer service calls.

Links: [{"title":"Natural language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language"},{"title":"Natural language understanding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_understanding"},{"title":"Natural language generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_generation"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Natural-language user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural-language_user_interface"},{"title":"Natural Language Toolkit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Language_Toolkit"},{"title":"Modality (semantics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modality_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Template:Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Natural approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_approach"}]

I've performed a web search for "Natural language" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition
A natural language is any spoken language or signed language used organically in a human community, first emerging without conscious premeditation and subject to replication across generations of people in the community, regional expansion or contraction, and gradual internal evolution.

## What's Excluded
Excluded from the definition of natural language are: artificial and constructed languages, such as those developed for works of fiction; languages of formal logic, such as those in computer programming; and non-human communication systems in nature, such as whale vocalizations or honey bees' waggle dance.

## Related Fields

**Natural Language Processing (NLP):** Natural language processing is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.

**Natural Language Understanding (NLU):** Natural language understanding is a subset of natural language processing in artificial intelligence that deals with machine reading comprehension.

**Natural Language Generation (NLG):** Natural language generation is a software process that produces natural language output.

**Natural Language Interfaces:** A natural-language user interface is a type of computer human interface where linguistic phenomena such as verbs, phrases and clauses act as UI controls for creating, selecting and modifying data in software applications.

These fields are fundamental to modern AI applications, including chatbots, voice assistants, and machine translation systems.

I've performed a web search for "Natural language" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition
A natural language is any spoken language or signed language used organically in a human community, first emerging without conscious premeditation and subject to replication across generations of people in the community, regional expansion or contraction, and gradual internal evolution.

## What's Excluded
Excluded from the definition of natural language are: artificial and constructed languages, such as those developed for works of fiction; languages of formal logic, such as those in computer programming; and non-human communication systems in nature, such as whale vocalizations or honey bees' waggle dance.

## Related Fields

**Natural Language Processing (NLP):** Natural language processing is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.

**Natural Language Understanding (NLU):** Natural language understanding is a subset of natural language processing in artificial intelligence that deals with machine reading comprehension.

**Natural Language Generation (NLG):** Natural language generation is a software process that produces natural language output.

**Natural Language Interfaces:** A natural-language user interface is a type of computer human interface where linguistic phenomena such as verbs, phrases and clauses act as UI controls for creating, selecting and modifying data in software applications.

These fields are fundamental to modern AI applications, including chatbots, voice assistants, and machine translation systems.

Web search results for query: "AI alignment"

Links: [{"title":"AI alignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_alignment"},{"title":"Talk:AI alignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:AI_alignment"},{"title":"The Alignment Problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Alignment_Problem"},{"title":"Alignment Research Center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alignment_Research_Center"},{"title":"Krishnan Gopi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnan_Gopi"},{"title":"Paul Christiano - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Christiano_(researcher)"},{"title":"AI trust paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_Trust_Paradox"},{"title":"Google Gemini - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Engineering Biology Research Consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering_Biology_Research_Consortium"},{"title":"Alan Winfield - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Winfield"}]

Here are the web search results for "AI alignment":

## Overview

AI alignment is an open problem for modern AI systems and is a research field within AI.(no content)In the field of artificial intelligence (AI), alignment aims to steer AI systems toward a person's or group's intended goals, preferences, or ethical principles.

## Key Concepts

Aligning AI involves two main challenges: carefully specifying the purpose of the system (outer alignment) and ensuring that the system adopts the specification robustly (inner alignment).(no content)An AI system is considered aligned if it advances the intended objectives. A misaligned AI system pursues unintended objectives.

## Challenges

It is often challenging for AI designers to align an AI system because it is difficult for them to specify the full range of desired and undesired behaviors. Therefore, AI designers often use simpler proxy goals, such as gaining human approval. But proxy goals can overlook necessary constraints or reward the AI system for merely appearing aligned.(no content)AI systems may also find loopholes that allow them to accomplish their proxy goals efficiently but in unintended, sometimes harmful, ways (reward hacking).

## Broader Context

AI alignment is a subfield of AI safety, the study of how to build safe AI systems. Other subfields of AI safety include robustness, monitoring, and capability control.(no content)Research challenges in alignment include instilling complex values in AI, developing honest AI, scalable oversight, auditing and interpreting AI models, and preventing emergent AI behaviors like power-seeking.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Large language model"

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"BERT (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BERT_(language_model)"},{"title":"ELMo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ELMo"},{"title":"PaLM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PaLM"},{"title":"Transformer (machine learning model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model)"},{"title":"GPT-3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3"}]

## Large Language Models (LLMs)

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

### Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

### Capabilities and Training

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

However, these models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

### Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.(no content)Open-weight LLMs have increasingly shaped the field since 2023, contributing to broader participation in AI development and greater transparency in model evaluation.

Links: [{"title":"Convention (norm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(norm)"},{"title":"Social norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norm"},{"title":"Category:Social conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_conventions"},{"title":"Category:Cultural conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cultural_conventions"},{"title":"Comedy of manners - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_of_manners"},{"title":"Convention (meeting) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(meeting)"},{"title":"Conventionalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conventionalism"},{"title":"List of International Labour Organization Conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ILO_Conventions"},{"title":"Cultural code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_code"},{"title":"Social constructionism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social conventions:

## Definition and Nature

In sociology, a social rule refers to any social convention commonly adhered to in a society.(no content)These rules are not written in law or otherwise formalized.(no content)A convention influences a set of agreed, stipulated, or generally accepted standards, social norms, or other criteria, often taking the form of a custom.

## Key Characteristics

The word often refers to unwritten customs shared throughout a community.(no content)A social norm or norm is a shared standard of acceptable behavior by a group.(no content)Norms are contingent on context, social group, and historical circumstances.

## How They Change Over Time

A social rule changes over time within the same society; what was acceptable in the past may no longer be the case, and rules differ across space: what is acceptable in one society may not be so in another.

## Examples

It is conventional in many societies that strangers being introduced shake hands.(no content)It is a social norm to provide tips in the US to waitresses and waiters.

## Consequences of Deviation

Deviance is defined as "nonconformity to a set of norms that are accepted by a significant number of people in a community or society."(no content)In the sociological literature, this can often lead to them being considered outcasts of society.

Social conventions are thus essential to maintaining social order, though they remain flexible and subject to change across time and cultural contexts.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social conventions:

## Definition and Nature

In sociology, a social rule refers to any social convention commonly adhered to in a society.(no content)These rules are not written in law or otherwise formalized.(no content)A convention influences a set of agreed, stipulated, or generally accepted standards, social norms, or other criteria, often taking the form of a custom.

## Key Characteristics

The word often refers to unwritten customs shared throughout a community.(no content)A social norm or norm is a shared standard of acceptable behavior by a group.(no content)Norms are contingent on context, social group, and historical circumstances.

## How They Change Over Time

A social rule changes over time within the same society; what was acceptable in the past may no longer be the case, and rules differ across space: what is acceptable in one society may not be so in another.

## Examples

It is conventional in many societies that strangers being introduced shake hands.(no content)It is a social norm to provide tips in the US to waitresses and waiters.

## Consequences of Deviation

Deviance is defined as "nonconformity to a set of norms that are accepted by a significant number of people in a community or society."(no content)In the sociological literature, this can often lead to them being considered outcasts of society.

Social conventions are thus essential to maintaining social order, though they remain flexible and subject to change across time and cultural contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
## Task Completed Successfully ✓

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations" and extracted all key entities. Here's a summary:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution
- The paper proposes novel experimental results demonstrating emergent phenomena in LLM populations

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

| Entity | Type | Relation | Purpose |
|--------|------|----------|---------|
| Large language model | artifact | uses | Primary subject of experimentation |
| Social norm | concept | proposes | Core phenomenon being demonstrated |
| Shared information bias | concept | proposes | Type of collective bias emerging in populations |
| Natural language | concept | uses | Communication medium for agents |
| Intelligent agent | concept | uses | Framework for autonomous agents |
| Multi-agent system | concept | uses | System architecture being studied |
| AI alignment | concept | proposes | Design implications for value alignment |

**Validation Results:**
- ✅ All 7 triples passed validation
- ✅ At least 1 "uses" relation present (requirement met)
- ✅ At least 1 "proposes" relation present for contribution paper (requirement met)
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid

The triples_output.json file has been updated with complete, validated data.
